title: Roughly 40 state attorneys general plan to take part in Facebook antitrust probe, sources say
text:
New York Attorney General Letitia James is spearheading the states' investigation into Facebook. (Mary Altaffer/AP)

Roughly 40 state attorneys general plan to take part in a New York-led antitrust investigation into Facebook, reflecting a broadening belief among the country’s top Democrats and Republicans that the tech giant may be undermining its social-networking rivals.

The heightened interest — confirmed Monday by three people familiar with the matter — comes weeks after New York’s Letitia James first announced a wide-ranging probe with seven other states and the District of Columbia to explore whether, in James’ words at the time, Facebook has “endangered consumer data, reduced the quality of consumers’ choices, or increased the price of advertising.”

The sources requested anonymity to discuss the investigation because such inquiries are confidential. The sources said that New York continues to solicit support from other states, meaning the number could still grow before it is formally announced.

A spokesperson for James in New York declined to comment.

On Monday, Facebook pointed to its previous statement from Will Castleberry, the company’s vice president of state and local policy, who said the company would “work constructively with state attorneys general and we welcome a conversation with policymakers about the competitive environment in which we operate.”

[Facebook, Google face off against a formidable new foe: State attorneys general]

The expanding state investigation into Facebook illustrates the broad, bipartisan concerns among the country’s top law enforcement officials that some companies in Silicon Valley have become too big and powerful, harming consumers and corporate rivals. Texas is leading a probe into Google’s advertising business that has the support of nearly every other state attorney general.

The state inquiry of Facebook comes in addition to two other antitrust investigations into the social-networking behemoth taking in place in Washington, one by the Department of Justice and the other by the Federal Trade Commission. Facebook has acknowledged the FTC inquiry in recent securities filings. The agency is exploring the company’s past acquisitions, including Instagram and WhatsApp, for possible violations of antitrust law.

On Monday, James and other attorneys general huddled with FTC and DOJ officials to discuss Facebook, her office later confirmed. Axios first reported the meeting news.

Last week, Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg pledged to “go to the mat” on antitrust during a private conversation with employees later unearthed by The Verge, a technology news site. Reflecting on the presidential aspirations of Sen. Elizabeth Warren, a Democratic candidate who’s vowed to challenge Silicon Valley on antitrust grounds, Zuckerberg pledged the company would mount a vigorous fight in court.

“If she gets elected president, then I would bet that we will have a legal challenge, and I would bet that we will win the legal challenge. And does that still suck for us? Yeah,” he said.

“I don’t want to have a major lawsuit against our own government," he continued. "I mean, that’s not the position that you want to be in when you’re, you know, I mean … it’s like, we care about our country and want to work with our government and do good things. But look, at the end of the day, if someone’s going to try to threaten something that existential, you go to the mat and you fight.”

authors: Tony Romm Is A Technology Policy Reporter At The Washington Post. He Has Spent Nearly Ten Years Covering The Ways That Tech Companies Like Apple
Google Navigate The Corridors Of Government --
